newsitem.title: SLOVENIA: Slovenia shares slip, pushed down by BTC.
newsitem.headline: Slovenia shares slip, pushed down by BTC.

text.p: Slovenia's SBI index ended marginally lower on Friday, driven lower by a four percent fall in warehouse and shopping centre operator BTC.

"Outlook of our market is really sad -- turnover is low and I don't think it'll get much better once foreigners return, because they will remain cautious regarding the stability of our market," said Karmen Cerar, a trader at brokerage Poteza.
The SBI index fell 0.37 percent or 4.87 points to 1,318.47. This week the blue-chip index firmed 1.55 percent.
"Next week prices are likely to move by a maximum one percent on similar volumes as this week," Cerar said.

The Bank of Slovenia earlier this year blocked foreign investment, forcing international portfolio investors to open special share trading custodian accounts at one of the country's 14 fully licensed banks.
Since then the SBI index has dropped by over 20 percent and average daily volume has fallen over 75 percent.
The first accounts are expected to be opened in June.
Traders said foreign buyers may refrain from trading as long as parliament does not ratify the EU association accord, signed in June last year.
"If the accord is not signed prices could fall deeper than ever before," Cerar added.
Last week the parliament postponed the ratification to allow more time for political parties to reach a broader agreement on the issue.
The Constitutional Court is expected to say next week whether the ratification of the agreement was in line with the constitution.
Overall four shares fell, eight rose and one was flat, while 15 were untraded. Turnover fell to 55.1 million tolars from 66.0 million.
BTC was the most active and the leading decliner, falling four percent to 14,400 tolars on volume of 1,000 shares for total turnover of 14.6 million tolars.
Traders said BTC was down on profit-taking after last week's gains when BTC announced plans to seek fresh capital in order to finance new investment.
Food maker Droga was the biggest gainer, rising 2.50 percent to 28,700 tolars on volume of 182 shares, for total turnover of 5.1 million tolars.
Traders attributed the rise to expectations of a dividend payout.
